### 5.1. Regulatory elements The regulatory elements reflect laws and sanctions that regulate the behavior of firms and individuals (North, 1990). Regulatory processes involve the setting of rules and their enforcement. Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore all possess some different laws concerning venture capital. The regulatory dimension in the three regions was consistently found to have an impact on how East Asian venture capitalistsfund newfirms.It wasalsofoundthat the regulatory dimension also significantly impacts exit from the funded firms. Each of these findings will be reviewed in turn. #### 5.1.1.Investment selection In the West venture capitalists rely on financial and accounting information contained in the business plan to initially evaluate the proposal (McGrath, 1997; Wright, Thompson, & Robbie, 1992).7 Additionally, venture capitalists in the West use information present in the plan to assess the risk of the proposed ventures (Wright et al., 1992). While venture capital firms in East Asia prefer to fund firms that have established financials, the regulatory institutions (items set by law) impact the quality of the information presented. Timely, accurate, or useful information about the financial performance can be difficult to obtain. Thus, if a firm is not already established (three years of financials) the risks are typically considered too high for funding in East Asia, unless the firm's technology and business plan is exceptional. The selection process is also made more challenging by the difficulty of obtaining reliable data from which to conduct due diligence. One Singapore based venture capitalist commented ‘since investors have less protection here [in Singapore] than in the West, it helps to have other means to screen and select and investments.? The venture capitalists generally agreed that as legal protection against fraud is weaker and market and accounting information have numerous deficiencies in East Asia, it is helpful to know the principal of the funded firm and his or her family. Added another Singapore-based venture capitalist, "this provides added protection as the firm principal is less likely to disappear or drop out of the investment because you know that individual as well as his or her family."’ Observed another Singapore-based venture capitalist: ... I apply [the importance of relationships] to venture capital and private equity deal making, both on the hiring side and investing side. For example, I love to do deals with people I have done deals with before. So you will find that although we might have done sixty or seventy transactions over the years, they have not been done with sixty or seventy different entrepreneurs, they have been done with twenty-five to thirty entrepreneurs. Many of them are repeat deals. The biggest risk in our business . . . is the people risk and when you do a repeat thing with the guy you have a good experience with, you have eliminated what I consider the biggest risk in the business—the people risk. Thus, while knowing firm principals, or knowing people that do, in the West is important in East Asia it was deemed so significant that it was a barrier that is difficult to surmount, if not impossible to overcome, in the selection process across East Asia. Overall, the selection process proved more difficult than in the West because the data that enables due diligence may not be readily available in East Asia. In addition, the absence of many legal protections and lack of case precedent in these countries generally make the enforcement of the contracts more difficult if problems arise.8 Thus we propose: Proposition 1:The less developed regulatory institutionsinEastAsiaoftenleadstoanabsenceofvalid andreliableinformationonafirmseekingfunding.As a result the selection process of firms to fund is more difficult and time consuming forventure capitalists in EastAsia. #### 5.1.2. Exit Another area that the weakness of regulatory structures impact is exit from the venture. In the West venture capital firms are usually organized as limited partnerships with a fixed life (Sahlman, 1988). Thus, the goal of most venture capital firms is to exit their investments through initial public offering (IPO) in five to seven years. Most private equity investors in East Asia also expect to exit through IPOs or strategic sales of the funded firm, although a shorter time frame of two to three years is common since the ventures that are funded are typically more mature in East Asia. However, exiting can be problematic, even from successful, growing ventures. In Taiwan the TASDAQ is fairly well established but in Hong Kong and Singapore it is considered more difficult for young firms to obtain a listing on a stock market, and even when it does occur it usually takes much longer (Wang & Sim, 2001). Thus venture capitalists pointed out that a more frequently employed exit strategy in these locales is to have the firm locate a strategic buyer. However, finding such ideal strategic partners can be challenging, and when exiting via a sale to a strategic partner, the multiple paid on the firm's revenue stream results in a return significantly lower than that traditionally associated with an IPO. One result of these exit difficulties is that many venture capital firms have discovered that when they do exit, their returns have not been as high as expected. Private equity firms in East Asia regularly reported a targetof $20-30\%$ return, but actual returns for many funds have been much lower (Asia Pacific Private Equity Bulletin, 1998). A number of different regions have announced the introduction of NASDAQ-type markets for smaller firms, such as Taiwan's TASDAQ and Hong Kong's Growth Enterprise Market (GEM). These new markets may help alleviate the exit problem for venture capitalists to some degree. Nevertheless, because of reduced liquidity in the market and stricter listing laws exit through an IPO is far from straightforward (Wang & Sim, 2001). Thus we propose: Proposition 2: The underdeveloped regulatory institutions in East Asia suppress the development of listing mechanisms for new startup firms. The resulting exit from fundedventures inEast Asia will bemore constrained and complex for the venture capitalist thanintheWest. ### 5.2. Normative elements The normative elements of an institutional system are those well-accepted values, beliefs and practices shared by professions, groups and opinion leaders in a field, often propagated through education, textbooks, training and consulting (DiMaggio, 2001; Scott, 1995). Venture capital requires extensive interaction between the venture capitalist and the entrepreneur they fund. Particularly, the monitoring of the funded firm requires extensive interaction since the published information may not provide an accurate indication of the firm's performance. Thus, the normative values of the venture capitalist and how these values interact with those of the funded entrepreneur in monitoring the firm will be reviewed in turn. #### 5.2.1. Values East Asian venture capital norms generally proved similar to what is known about venture capitalists in the West from authors such as Fried and Hisrich (1995). The venture capital industry in East Asia developed principally as individuals and firms from the U.S. and Europe moved into East Asia. The result is that most venture capitalists in East Asia have worked for or been trained in the U.S. or Europe. Additionally, venture capital associations hold training programs throughout East Asia that encourage professional standards that are very similar to U.S. venture capitalist. These two factors help to produce a set of normative values among the venture capitalists very consistent with those from venture capitalists in the West.? Thus we propose: # Proposition 3: Normative values of venture capitalists in East Asia will generally bevery similar to those found in theWest. #### 5.2.2. Monitoring The venture capitalist must interact with entrepreneurs of funded firms extensively in monitoring investments. Thus, the normative values of indigenous entrepreneurs must also be considered in examining the venture capitalist actions in this domain (Lau et al., 2002). The result is that one key difference in normative practice from that of the West that emerged in East Asia is that monitoring is done much more through personal interactions with the entrepreneur who founds the firm. In the West venture capitalists monitor their investment mostly through direct interaction with the entrepreneur. However, venture capitalists and the entrepreneur know that they will also monitor the investment through firm financials and via the venture capitalist's membership on the board of directors (Fried, Bruton, & Hisrich,1998;Fried & Hisrich, 1992, 1995; Rosenstein,1988; Sapienza, 1992). Accounting rules and reporting standards around East Asia can deviate significantly from international norms (Broadman, 1999; Low, 2000; Peng, 2000). Even in those cases that there are financials produced by one of the established international accounting firms, there can be considerable concerns about the validity of the information presented. As one venture capitalist interviewed recalled, “just because there are audited statements from an international accounting firm does not mean there are not multiple sets of books in the firm." Another venture capitalist added that you should be prepared to go into a firm and count things yourself. Thus, the normative values of entrepreneurs help to shape the utility of the company information that the venture capitalist will receive. In terms of monitoring via the board, it cannot be assumed that the venture capitalist will receive a board seat in East Asia (Low, 2002). But even if a board seat is obtained it may not mean what it does in the West. As noted, corporate governance is weak in the three regions examined with only limited influence of outside directors (Peng, 2000). Additionally, the information received may be less than accurate. For example, one venture capitalist reported that it is not uncommon for the minutes of board meetings to be written before the meeting has actually started, complete with readymade quotes from that venture capitalist. Therefore, some of the traditional means to monitor the funded firm in mature economies such as obtaining regular accounting and financial information and board membership may provide fewer insights in East Asia. If the venture capitalists are to properly monitor their investment they must develop trust with the entrepreneur so that they obtain the desired information and ensure its accuracy. Such trust between the funded firm and the venture capitalist is consistent with the nature of communication between parties in Chinese culture. In this cultural setting there are typically clear insiders and outsiders (Goa, Ting-Tooney, & Gundykunst, 1996), and the fow of information to outsiders is severely restricted. Several venture capitalists reported that they had to work very hard to build trust with their funded firms to secure even a modicum of information.Some of the same monitoring approaches used in the West are relevant, while other different circumstances and practices in East Asia compel venture capitalists to monitor investments differently, specifically focusing on building a relationship with the entrepreneur for which the project is funded. Thus we propose: Proposition 4: The normative values of funded entrepreneursresultinmonitoringactivitiesinEastAsia that require venture capitalists to place emphasis on having or building relationships with funded entrepreneurs. The result is that the monitoring time, effort and costs will be higher than those for venture capitalists in theWest. ### 5.3. Cognitive elements The cognitive elements of institutions are commonly transmitted through culture, of which in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan, is predominantly the culture of the Overseas Chinese (Chen, 2001; Jepperson, 1991; Scott, 2002). Overseas Chinese culture particularly impacts actions of managers by imparting greater importance to relationships among business people, thus impacting how venture capitalists can add value to funded firms (Chen, 2001). The interviews revealed that the venture capitalists see the cultural/cognitive institutional elements (Scott, 2002) as having a great impact on their day to day activities. For example, these elements have a significant impact on the nature of the value added venture capitalists can provide to funded firms. The interviewees stressed the U.S. venture capital industry infuences their training. The terms they used, their goals, and the values they expressed as to what the appropriate actions were for venture capitalists were generally consistent with those expressed by venture capitalists in the U.s. However, it was clear in these discussions that the venture capitalists in East Asia also are influenced by the environment in which they compete. The weaker regulatory system in East Asia in particular means that the culture of the region may become even more important in assuring that the actions desired are actually pursued (Chen, 2001). The ability of venture capitalists to compel a funded firm to perform certain activities is constrained by the weaker legal and enforcement regime in East Asia. Thus, culture as a means of influencing behavior becomes even more salient. Reflected one Singapore venture capitalist: In the [United] States, you have laws that people respect and are enforced. In Asia, that is often not the case. At our company, we try to do deals with people we know, or others know. And it helps if [the entrepreneur's] family is here also. Then we can get to know them. This way, it makes it harder for people to slack off, or even skip town with our money. We can always go to his family and ask what is happening with their son. They usually will not want to be embarrassed. . . This [influence of the family]is helpful with our due diligence and monitoring. When examining a widespread ethnic group across different industries and countries, particularly in locales whose regulatory regimes are not extensively developed, the cognitive-based institutions, transmitted primarily through the local culture are a focus of concern (Chen, 2001; Jepperson, 1991; Peng & Heath, 1996). As noted before, the culture of East Asia has already been known for its strong influence on managerial behavior resulting in actions that differ from what would occur in similar situations in the West (Chen, 2001). Two particularly important aspects of cognitive institutions will be examined in turn. #### 5.3.1. Guanxi One particular cultural issue stood out in the interviews. It was noted previously that the commercial regulatory regime in East Asia is still weak in many areas. One means that has developed to assure performance across a wide range of businesses is that there should be a relationship of some type between the parties. The relationship may not be sufficient to assure that the business activity between the two parties occurs but it is a necessary condition before the business activity is even considered. This relationship can be such that the parties went to the same school, their families are friends, they are related, or share significant business interests with others. The effect of such relationships is that cultural control is established. As a result, in East Asia some relationships between the venture capitalist and the funded firm's top management may have to be present for funding to be considered. Relationships between venture capitalists and their relevant networks of investors, entrepreneurs, and other venture capitalists are also important in the U.S. (Bartlett, 1995), but in East Asia guanxi or connections between various parties are particularly crucial. Guanxi is very helpful to the venture capitalist in conducting due diligence, successfully interacting with the firm, and ensuring the firm achieves the desired results. Thus we propose: Proposition 5: Cognitive institutional elements in East Asia will result in the actions of venture capitalists being particularly impacted by the consequences of guanxi. #### 5.3.2. Value added to funded firm One of strengths of venture capital in the West is the value added to the firm by the venture capitalist (Bygrave, 1987; Zider, 1998). Providing value added to the firm through advice and services provided is also increasingly the case in East Asia's venture capital industry (Ahlstrom et al., 2000). However, this is a recent change. Initial private equity investors tended to be passive financial investors. But, increasingly, the interest is to provide added value to the firm in a manner consistent with venture capitalists in the West. In the U.s., for example, the advice provided to the CEO of the funded firm is often very direct and may occur in regular interaction between the venture capitalist and the CEO (Fried & Hisrich, 1995). However, in East Asia the manner in which the venture capitalist typically provides the advice to the CEO is different. As noted, the CEO of the firm culturally plays a paternal role that impacts the flow of information and organization. Thus, the venture capitalist in East Asia must deal appropriately with the key cultural factor of minzi—face or respect. In other words, the appearance of appropriate difference to an individual's status in the society and the firm. It is arguable that even in the West the issue of face is important. However, its relative greater importance in a Chinese-based culture is widely recognized (Bond, 1988). Additionally, in Chinese culture there is a bias to avoid conflict. Therefore, several venture capitalists indicated that one needs to advise a manager in a manner that allows the maintaining of face and avoiding of conflict. For example, rather than giving an ultimatum, an idea might be put forth as a suggestion. One Hong Kong venture capitalist commented: The setting where suggestions are provided is important. A venture capitalist should never make bold suggestions in front of a manager's subordinates. The venture capitalist should take the manager aside and make the recommendation in private. This way, the manager can remain “in charge’ and take credit for the changes. It is important to give face to the entrepreneurs you fund—some are very sensitive to this. Thus we propose: Proposition 6: Cognitive institutional elements in East Asia exert strong infuence on the manner in which value is added to the firm by venture capitalists. ## 6. Discussion The evidence here suggests that a range of institutional elements present in East Asia influence the actions of venture capitalists located in the region, in spite of similar training and norms as venture capitalists in the West. These institutions create several differences from venture capital practice in the West that venture capitalists and investors need to be aware. The institutional elements (regulatory, normative, cognitive) can all exert influence; however, the less formal cognitive institutional elements may play the strongest role. In particular, the cognitive institutions as exemplified by the Overseas Chinese commercial culture strongly shape the behavior of the venture capitalist in East Asia. The Western and East Asian models of venture capital developed within very distinct institutional frameworks (Scott, 1995, 2002). In East Asia the distinguishing characteristic includes the fact that most East Asian economies have a deeply entrenched concentrated ownership structure, with significant family control of firms, and interlocking shareholdings among firms, characteristic of Overseas Chinese business practice (Allen, 2000; Chen, 2001; Zhuang, 1999). These normative and cognitive institutions combine with the weak regulatory system and poor corporate governance (regulatory institutions) to create different and unusual challenges for venture capitalists working in East Asia. These distinctive institutions have led to many differences in the implementation of the various activities by the venture capital industry in East Asia. For example, the nature of the regulatory institutions means venture capitalists must conduct due diligence as part of their firm selection quite carefully. One Singapore-based venture capitalist related a story that during a due diligence investigation it was found that a funded firm failed to have much of the inventory that was stated on its books. The inventory was actually being held by a sister firm in a different part of SouthEast Asia. When asked about it, the funded company founder retorted that the inventory was still under its control, albeit some 1,500 kilometers from where it was reported to have been, and that there was nothing to worry about. The lack of regulatory institutions and sometimes different commercial norms makes close monitoring of funded firms quite important in East Asia, albeit challenging. Venture capitalists in the three regions examined often fund businesses that have some activities in Mainland China as well. The difficulties in implementing venture capital activities there are even more severe because of the paucity of laws and their enforcement in many industrial sectors (Ahlstrom, Young, & Nair, 2002; Bruton & Ahlstrom, 2002; Lubman, 1999). To illustrate, the need for due diligence in China is even more critical since assets can gradually or even suddenly disappear if not watched carefully, with the complicity of the local law enforcement (Ahlstrom et al., 2002). For example, one Hong Kong-based private equity firm helped to fund an existing business that was long established. However, due to the inability to properly do (personal) due diligence and monitor the China-based firm, the private equity firm found that one day that firm had closed without any warning to anyone and the entrepreneur had taken everything of potential value from the funded firm. He even carted off all the porcelain toilets bathroom fixtures from every foor of the building. The nature of the normative institutional elements present in the East Asian region also can impact the implementation of some common venture capital activities. For example, the difficulty in gathering needed information to monitor funded firms has led many venture capitalists to focus their efforts primarily on given geographic areas where they know people and can travel to regularly, rather than on specific industries as would be more common among venture capitalists in the West (Bruton et al., 2001). Additionally, the strong role of the owner/manager leads the individual to often view the funds provided by the venture capitalist to be their personal funds. One venture capitalist related how this view resulted in expenditures for houses and cars. Thus, venture capitalists must closely monitor the funds expenditures to ensure they are spent as intended. Similarly, owner/managers in the region see venture capitalists only as passive financial investors. Historically this has often been the role the venture capital industry was reduced to playing. However, today venture capitalists are seeking to be more active investors and provide value to the funded firm on different levels (Gupta, 2000). Thus, the venture capitalists today must often educate entrepreneurs about the venture capital process and their expectations. The cognitive element of guanxi also relates to another key implementation issue. For example, venture capitalists need to ensure that they understand not only the prospective funded firm's business model and capabilities, but also any local-partner relationships, and government connections the firm top management team (particular its founder) has. As one venture capitalist put it: In a business situation, try to understand the context of the word ‘friend’ or pengyou to learn what level of influence or actual guanxi really exists and whether your friend has the interest to use his or her friendship for you or for others to your benefit. Without the benefit of such guanxi or connections, the ability to judge the credit worthiness of the entrepreneurs and their idea is limited. Additionally, without such connections the ability to accurately monitor the funded firm can also be insufficient. The role of such connections also means that new venture capital firms must be careful to include key individuals who have such an understanding, or the venture capital firm will be at a disadvantage until it can build the necessary connections. Institutions in East Asia and their influence as compared to those of the West are summarized in Table 2. It is important to note that while there were broad similarities in the venture capital industries in the three countries examined there were also subtle differences. Among the three regions the Taiwanese industry was most focused on high technology investing. Thus, it was in Taiwan where high risk, high return venture capital investing was most likely to occur. For example, there is an established (although not closely regulated) gray market for shares of technology-focused firms prior to their public listing in Taiwan. The result of this market is that there is some exit opportunities for venture capitalists not available in the rest of Asia. Similarly, the role of the government in the venture capital industry in Singapore differs from that of the other two governments. The Singapore government provides an important part of the venture capital available in Singapore. The government has a nonintervention attitude towards the management of these funds. However, the government does encourage the funds to seek out international opportunities in the U.S. and Europe for investment. The belief is that such investments will strengthen the normative values of the venture capital industry in that nation and align them more with those of the venture capital industry in the West. As a result the Singapore venture capital industry is more focused on ensuring values and behaviors consistent with those in the U.S. or Europe. Thus, there are subtle but pervasive differences in the venture capital industries even in the three regions examined. Future research should examine these differences among other topics in the future. ### 6.1. The future of venture capital in East Asia There are significant differences between the venture capital industries of the West and East Asia. At the end of the interviews the venture capitalists and government officials also discussed their view of the future of venture capital in East Asia. Specifically, they focused on whether the differences identified here will persist over time or whether the Western and East Asian industries will converge in the future. As noted before, the normative values of the venture capitalists in the West and in Asia are generally similar due to the nature of their training and propagation of professional standards. However, it came clear in the resulting discussion there are other changes occurring among the normative institutions of the entrepreneurs in East Asia that are driving the venture capital industry in the West and Asia closer. The firms coming forward to ask for funding are no longer focused in more mature and primary resource industries. Instead, a variety of technopreneurial startups are increasingly considered for funding by venture capitalists in the East Asia. Moreover, the nature of the entrepreneurs coming forward to ask for funding is changing. Historically, most of the top graduates from universities in the region sought to go to work for large corporations. Today however, the best and the brightest from universities are increasingly seeking to start their own firms, particularly in high technology areas. These students’ models are great entrepreneurs from the West such as Bill Gates and Steven Jobs so they seek to act accordingly. Additionally, increasing numbers of prospective entrepreneurs are returning from universities in the West and are bringing new ideas and expectations for the venture capitalist with them. Finally, since many of the firms have a strong technology focus, the need for such businesses to more fully integrate and cooperate with other firms around the world encourages the firms to become more like those firms. Thus, firm selection can increasingly be expected to become more similar to the West. Additionally, entrepreneurs also increasingly understand that the venture capitalists can offer financial and strategic managerial advice that will help firms achieve their goals. Thus, they are more willing to share information with the venture capitalists and take their value added activities. There are changes in the institutions in East Asia that are providing means for these entrepreneurs to have their new startups publicly listed which, in turn, helps to increase the interest of high quality individuals. The opening in the region of exchanges such as Hong Kong's new Growth Enterprise Market stock market has created opportunities for entrepreneurs that did not exist before. The result is that the role of monitoring and exit will also become more similar to the West in the future. Thus, overall, it is likely that venture capitalists in East Asia will increasingly behave in manners very similar to their counterparts in the West. There are, however, institutional forces in East Asia that will continue to differ from those of the West. Although there are efforts in East Asia to change some of the laws and to improve enforcement and corporate governance, for instance, significant differences between the institutional profiles of the West and East Asia remain. These differences will mean that the practice of venture capital in East Asia will continue to vary from that of the West. ### 6.2. # Does venture capital stimulate the innovation of China's new energy enterprises?  

Jiang Cailou a,b, \*, Liu DeHai a  

DevelopmentInstituteof JiangbeiNanjingniversityof InformationScience&Technology,Nanjing21004,China ResearchInstituteforEnvironment andHealth,NanjingUniversityf InformationScience&TechnologyNanjing004,Chin  

# ARTICLEINFO  

# ABSTRACT  

Article history:   
Received 21 January 2021   
Received in revised form   
5 October 2021   
Accepted 19 November 2021   
Available online 20 November 2021   
Keywords:   
NE enterprises   
Innovation   
Venture capital   
Government participation   
Joint type   
Local investment  

With a sample of the listed new energy (NE) enterprises in China (2010-2017), this paper investigates the impact of venture capital on NE enterprises innovation by applying the Propensity Score Matching (PSM) model and Poisson model. The results indicate that venture capital has a positive and significant impact on the innovation of NE enterprises, among which the innovation incentive effect of government participation and joint venture capital is more significant. Compared with non-government participation venture capital, single venture capital and non-local investment, government participation venture capital, joint venture capital and local investment are more conducive to promoting the increase of patent applications of NE enterprises. Besides, local investment conducted by government participation venture capital and joint venture capital have a more significant innovation incentive effect of NE enterprises. This paper not only reveals the impact of venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises, but also provides the empirical basis for the government to adopt the market instrument to promote the development of NE industry.  

$\copyright$ 2021 Published by Elsevier Ltd.  

## 1. Introduction  

The traditional energy structure dominated by oil, coal and natural gas has not only increased the country's dependence on foreign imports and stimulated conflicts between energy supply and demand, but also further led to global warming and ecological environment deterioration. Therefore, accelerating the development and efficient utility of renewable NE turns out to be an inevitable way for countries to promote the upgrading of energy structure and environmental protection. The Chinese government has always attached great importance to the positive role of NE in coping with climate deterioration, energy shortage, and promoting energy conservation, emission reduction, and low-carbon green transformation [1-4]. In 2010 , the State Council promulgated the "Decision of the State Council on Accelerating the Cultivation and Development of Strategic Emerging Industries", which clearly classified NE as a strategic emerging innovative industry in China and mainly develops NE industries such as solar photovoltaic energy, wind power energy, hydro energy, nuclear energy, biomass energy, Marine energy, hydrogen energy, small hydropower and natural gas hydrate. In practical, China's NE industry started late and developed slowly, mainly rely on government subsidies and clean energy promotion projects to expand the NE industrial scale at the early stage. For example, during the period from 2009 to 2013, only two national key support projects in the photovoltaic power generation industry-Golden Sun Demonstration Project and Photovoltaic Construction Project, the government has subsidized them as much as 38 billion yuan. In the past decade, driven by strong promotion of government policies, China's NE industry has achieved a great leap forward [5]. In 2019, China's photovoltaic and wind power generation capacity reached 224.26 and 405.7 billion kilowatt-hours, and the cumulative installed capacity reached 2.043 and 2.1 million kilowatts respectively, which make it rank first in the world. At the same time, the scale of industries such as biomass energy, Marine energy, hydrogen energy, small hydropower, and natural gas hydrate is also expanding rapidly. Though government subsidy policies and clean energy promotion policies, in the short run, contributed to the simultaneous surge of installed capacity and electricity generation of NE industry, the phenomenon of overcapacity and insufficient innovation motivation is getting worse.Excessivegovernmentsubsidiestend todistortthemarket price of NE industry, induce NE enterprises to expand production to pursue economies of scale, reduce the motivation of NE enterprises to carry out innovation activities[6]. Technology innovation is an important index to measure a country's national comprehensive strength and international competitiveness. Therefore, under the background of the gradual exit of government subsidies policies in NE industry, NE enterprises urgently need to make full use of the market to allocate resources and constantly push the boundaries of technology to achieve sustainable industrial development through market means.  

NE industry is one of the most promising industries in the world, and has the characteristics of high investment, high risk and high potential profitability [7]. Venture capital is a new market-oriented means of financing, which can give NE enterprises greater flexibility and influence enterprise innovation by injecting capital and indirectly participating in management [8]. Under the background of the declining of government subsidies, it is of great significance tostudythe influence of themarket-orientedmeansofventure capital on the innovation of Chinese NE enterprises. Compared with the existing literature, this study makes contributions as follows: First of all, the NE industry is a strategic emerging industry in China. It is of great significance to investigate the impact of venture capital as a market-oriented financing method on the innovation of NE enterprises to realize the purpose of emission reduction and lowcarbon green development. Secondly, in view of the development status of venture capital industry, this study explores the different impacts of government participation and joint venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises from the perspective of venture capital heterogeneity, filling the gap in previous studies. Finally, from the perspective of geographic proximity, this study further analyzes the innovative effects of local investment in each region by government participation venture capital and local investment by joint venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises, which also provides a new perspective on the existing research of venture capital on enterprises innovation.  

## 2. Theoretical mechanism and research hypothesis  

### 2.1. Venture capital and NE enterprises innovation  

Currently, there is still controversy about the impact of venture capital on enterprise innovation. Some scholars argue that venture capital, constrained by experience, human resources and market rules, does not have the expected "incubation" effect on enterprise innovation. Chen (2011) [9] takes China's Growth Enterprise Market (GEM) high-tech enterprises as a research sample, and finds that venture capital failed to bring more innovation achievements and innovation benefits to invested enterprises. Using a study of 940 manufacturing andbusiness service sector enterprisesin the United States and the United Kingdom, Lahr and Mina (2016) [10] find that venture capital does not have a significant impact on enterprises innovation and even has a negative impact on future patent applications of the invested enterprise. However, most scholarshave certified the innovative effect of venture capital on enterprises. Wonglimpiyara (2007) [11] proves that in Thailand, Small and Medium-sized Development Bank can realize the diffusion and commercialization of national technological innovation by setting up venture capital to finance high-risk and high-potential technology start-ups. By using panel data from 17 EU countries, Faria (2014) [12] argues that venture capital can stimulate innovation in the later stage. In China, Wei et al. (2015) [13] believe that compared with bank loans, venture capital can more effectively enhance the green innovation capabilities of China's real industry. By taking GEM and Small Medium Enterprise (SME) board enterprises as the object, Zhang and Zhang (2016) [14], and Gu (2019) [15] find that enterprises with venture capital are more innovative and obtain more patents than those without venture capital, confirming that venture capital can effectively stimulate enterprises innovation.  

NE generation has problems of high operating costs and low market competitiveness [16]. In addition, the technology innovation of NE industry has high risks and large capital demands, it is difficult to completely rely on the NE enterprise's own funds for innovation. Venture capital is a kind of equity capital specialized in high-risk and potentially high-return project investment [17-19], which can influence the innovation of NE enterprises in the followingways.  

Firstly, venture capital can directly alleviate the constraints of innovative financing of enterprises by injecting capital into NE enterprises [20,21]. At the same time, it also sends positive"signals" of the quality of NE enterprises to external stakeholders [22-25], which can help broaden financing channels of enterprises. Using data from 133 Chinese enterprises , Zhang and Liao(2011) [20] examine the relationship between venture capital and enterprises Initial Public Offerings (IPO), and find that venture capital can provide enterprises with capital in addition to increasing their profitability in order to perform well in the stock market. By studying the treatment effect of venture capital on enterprise financial condition, Li et al. (2021) [23Jalso find that the involvement of venture capital can increase enterprise transparency and information disclosure, reduce information asymmetry between enterprise and external stakeholders, and thus increase the likelihood of commercial bank loans.  

Secondly, through indirect participation in enterprises management [26-29], venture capital institutions can bring advanced management and operation systems to NE enterprises,broaden NE enterprises sales channels through their own social networks, and provide material foundation for NE enterprises’ innovation [30-32]. Using a sample of Chinese GEM-listed enterprises, Chu et al. (2021) [33] find that venture capitals tend to participate in the internal enterprises governance and use equity and options to incentivize enterprises innovation. Savaneviciene (2015) [28] also believes that venture capital excels at employing professional talents to improve enterprise specialization, production efficiency and innovationpotential.  

Thirdly, Innovation capability is an important indicator to reflect the long-term value of an enterprise. Venture capital pays more attention to the cultivation of enterprise innovation capabilities, and achieves long-term growth of NE enterprises through the continuous development of new technologies and new products,in order to obtain excess investment returns when exiting [10]. By applying a multiple linear regression model, Jin et al. (2016) [34] investigate the relationship between venture capital and firm value appreciation, and find that venture capital can achieve enterprise value growth by increasing Research and Development(R&D）investment and developing new products. Based on the above analysis, the following hypotheses are proposed:  

H1. Venture capital has a positive and significant impact on the innovation of NE enterprises.  

### 2.2.Government participation venture capital and NE enterprises innovation  

In recent years, China has established government guidance funds and implemented preferential policies for venture capital to support the development and growth of innovative enterprises [35,36]. Such government participation venture capital usually has policy guidance and can use its own political network to provide scarce resource support for enterprises, ease the constraints of innovation financing, and provide innovation support for NE enterprises. Huang et al. (2020) [37] find that government participation venture capital can significantly promote the innovation of GEM listed enterprises and technology-based start-ups. Xie et al.(2018) [38] also argue that government participation venture capital can effectively promote the innovation of state-owned enterprises [33]. However, sometimes government venture capital deviates from the original policy intentions in practice, making it difficult to play a leading role in industrial innovation. Luukkonen et al.(2013) [39] believe that the contribution of European venture capital with a government background to the business philosophy and value-added management of high-tech enterprises is significantlylower than that of venture capitalwith other backgrounds [35]. Bertoni and Tykvova (2015) [40] take European biotech enterprises as a sample and found that venture capital with a government background did not promote enterprises innovation [35]. New energy is the key strategic emerging industry in China, and it is necessarytoexamine theimpact ofgovernmentparticipation venture capital on theinnovation of NE enterprises.Based on the development status of the NE industry, the following hypotheses areproposed:  

H2. Government participation venture capital is more conducive to the innovation of NE enterprises.  

### 2.3. Joint venture capital and NE enterprises innovation  

According to the number of venture capital institutions involved in NE enterprises, venture capital can be divided into independent venture capital and joint venture capital. Compared with independent venture capital, joint venture capital on one hand can provide more abundant funds and professional talents, on the other hand can improve the social network[41] and form resource complementary advantages for invested enterprises [42-44]. All these will provide good material foundation for the innovation of NE enterprises. Cheng and Tang (2019) [45] argue that in an uncertain industrial environment, independent venture capital institutions should work together to achieve excellent investment performance. Chen et al. (2017) [8] use data from China's A-share enterprises and find that the joint investment by multiple venture institutions can bring a variety of heterogeneous resources in terms of innovative technology and industry experience, which has a stronger effect on the innovation of invested enterprises. Taking the National Equities Exchange and Quotations (NEEQ) listed enterprises as a sample, Liu et al. (2018) [46] find that the joint investment composed of 5-6 venture capital institutions has the most significant impact on enterprise innovation [40]. However, some hold the opposing view that joint venture capital may also increase the cost of communication between venture capital institutions, or even increase the risk of competitive disclosure due to the sharing of venture capital information, which is not conducive to enterprise innovation. Dong et al. (2019) [47] argue that joint investment forms an indirect connection of competition among the invested enterprises, which can easily lead to competitive disclosure and hinder enterprises innovation. Considering that joint venture capital has abundant social network resources, which can help overcome the uncertainties of markets and technologies of NE industry, this paper proposes the following hypotheses:  

H3. Joint venture capital is more conducive to the innovation of NEenterprises.  

### 2.4. Local investment by venture capital and NE enterprises innovation  

Since China's regional economic development level is varied, the distribution of venture capital institutions is imbalanced, mainly gathered in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and other developed cities. From the perspective of geographical proximity, the local investment ofventure capitalinstitutions can enjoy thefinancial resources and relatively perfect intellectual property protection system brought by the process of local city's marketization, which can improve the exit performance of venture capital institutions and the innovation motivation of invested NE enterprises [48,49]. Meanwhile, in the process of local investment, geographical cluster can effectively reduce the information asymmetry of financial market, help venture capital institutions to select suitable enterprises, reduce the cost of communication and management with invested enterprises, and better provide innovative value-added services for NE enterprises, so as to gain a high reputation for investment [50]. By investigating the impact of environmental uncertainty on local investment by venture capital from the perspective of micro enterprises and macro market, Huang et al. (2015)[51]find that when the invested enterprises are high-tech enterprises, venture capital institutions are faced with higher agency costs and investment risks and are more inclined to invest in local enterprises, when the level of regional financial development is high and the atmosphere of innovation is good,venture capital is more willing to choose local investment as well. The development of NE industry has a high externality of geographical aggregation and relies on the collaborative innovation development of upstream and downstream supply chains. Venture capital investment institutions choose localization, can further narrow the scope of the innovation supply chain of NE enterprises, increase the sharing of innovative heterogeneous resources, and have a positive impact on the innovation of NE enterprises. Therefore, this paper puts forward the following hypothesis:  

H4. Local investment of venture capital is more conducive to the innovation of NE enterprise.  

## 3. Research design  

### 3.1. Data sources  

This paper selects China's listed NE enterprises from 2010 to 2017 as the research object. The amount of venture capital obtained by NE enterprises and the specificinformation ofventure capital institutionscomesfromtheCVSourcedatabase.Totalassets,net profit, asset-liability ratio, government subsidies and age of establishment of NE enterprises are obtained from CSMAR database. Part of the missing data of government subsidies is supplemented through the annual reports oflisted enterprises and www. cninfo.com. The number of patent applications of NE enterprises comes from the State Intellectual Property Office, and some missing patent data are supplemented by the enterprise's prospectus.  

### 3.2. Model setting  

#### 3.2.1. PSM method  

Considering that NE enterprises with higher innovation capability may be easier to attract venture capital, and venture capital institutions may also prefer to invest in NE enterprises with higher innovation capability. This may lead to selective bias in samples, and result in the deviation of the parameter estimation results. Since the principle of PSM method is to construct the propensity score according to multi-dimensional characteristic variables,and to find the samples that are closest to the experimental group from the control group for matching, this study adopt the PSM method to process the samples, and estimates the net effect of venture capital on NE enterprises innovation by comparing the innovation difference of NE enterprises with andwithout venture capital.NE enterprises with venture capital involvement are classified into experimental group, and those without venture capital involvement are classified into control group. The Logit model is used to estimate the propensity matching score of NE enterprises to introduce venture capital. The calculation model is as follows:  

$$
P(Z_{i})=P[V C_{i}=1|Z_{i}]=\frac{\exp(\beta Z_{i})}{1+\exp(\beta Z_{i})}
$$  

Among them, $P(Z i)$ represents the propensity matching score of NE enterprises introducing venture capital. $V C i=1$ represents that NE enterprises have introduced venture capital, and $V C i=0$ represents that NE enterprises have not introduced venture capital. Zi represents the matching variable.  

#### 3.2.2. Measurement model  

Besides venture capital, the innovation of China's NE enterprises is also affected by internal factors such as enterprise size, net profit, debt ratio, enterprise's nature, and government subsidies. In order to study the impact of venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises, the following model is constructed:  

$$
p a t e n t_{i t}=\alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1}V C_{i t}+\sum_{k=1}^{N}\beta_{k}C o n t r o l_{i t}+\delta_{i}+\varphi_{t}+\varepsilon_{i t}
$$  

Among them, i represents the enterprise and t represents the year.Patent is the explained variable,which is used to measure the innovation of NE enterprises. $V C$ is the key explanatory variable, represents the amount of venture capital. Control represents all Control variables, $\delta,\quad\varphi$ represents the industry and year fixed effects respectively, $\varepsilon_{i t}$ represents the random error term.  

### 3.3. Variable set  

The explained variable is the number of patent applications (patent) of NE enterprises. Compared with the R&D investment of enterprises, the number of patents can accurately measure the innovation output of enterprises, and better reflect the innovation capability of NE enterprises. Considering the hysteresis of patent authorization and the uncertainty factors in the application process, this paper finally selects the number of patent applications of NE enterprises as the explained variable [52].  

The core explanatory variable is the current venture capital stock (VC) of NE enterprises. With reference to the research of Wu (2006) [53], and Qi et al.(2017) [54], the perpetual inventory method is used here to calculate the current venture capital stock of NEenterprises:  

$$
\mathsf{V C}_{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{V C_{-}N_{t}}{F_{t}}+(1-\hat{\delta}_{t})V C_{t-1}
$$  

Among them, $V C\_N_{\mathrm{{t}}}$ represents the amount of venture capital obtained by NE enterprises in the current period, $\mathrm{F_{t}}$ represents the fixed asset investment price index of the current period, and $V C_{\mathrm{t-1}}$ represents the venture capital stock of NE enterprises in the previousperiod. $\delta_{t}$ represents the current depreciationrate.The variable depreciation rate of each industry to which NE enterprises belongs can be calculated through the "CHINA INDUSTRY ECONOMY STATISTIC YEARB0OK" (2003-2017).  

Enterprise innovation may be affected by its own characteristics. According to the research of Chen et al. (2017) [8], and Qi et al. (2015) [54], six control variables of enterprise size (size), Net profit rate of total assets (roa), Asset-liability ratio (lev), Government subsidies $(s u b)$ ,Shareholder holdings (top10) and age of establishment (age) are introduced in this paper. Among them, the enterprise size (size) is represented by the logarithm of the total assets of  

NE enterprise.The netprofit rate of total assets(roa)is expressed as the ratio of the enterprise's net profit to the average total assets, which measures the profitability of NE enterprise. Asset-liability ratio(lev)is expressed as the total debt to the total assets,which measures thefinancialleverageof NEenterprise.Government subsidies $(s u b)$ is represented by the logarithm of the amount of government subsidies. Shareholder holdings (top10) is expressed by the shareholding ratio of the top ten shareholders. The age of establishment (age) is expressed by the time the company was established as of 2017. The knowledge accumulation and R&D foundation of NE enterprise are related to the age of establishment.  

In order to eliminate the impact of heteroscedasticity, the stock of venture capital, enterprise size and government subsidies are added by 1 to perform logarithmic processing respectively, and roa, lev and top 10 were multiplied by 100. Table 1 shows the descriptive statistics of the whole sample, and Table 2 shows the descriptive statistics of the sub-sample of NE enterprises with and without the intervention of venture capital (the experimental group and control group). Table 3 is the correlation analysis. Overall, the correlation coefficients between most variables are lower than 0.5, which means and the problem of multi-collinearity is not serious.  

## 4. Empirical analysis  

### 4.1. PSM empirical analysis  

In this paper, NE enterprises with venture capital intervention were classified into experimental group, and NE enterprises without venture capital intervention were classified into the control group. Excluding enterprises with a lot of missing data, 69 enterprises were finally obtained as the experimental group and 81 enterprises as the control group. First, our paper uses the nearest collar matching method for one-to-one matching. Fig. 1a and Fig. 1b show that before matching, there is a huge difference between the experimental group and the control group. After the matching, the variable characteristics of the experimental group and the control group are closer. From the variable balance table in Table 4, there are significant differences in the variables of the experimental group and the control group before the matching (U). After the matching (M), the deviations of the variables of the experimental group and the control group are within $10\%$ and the p value is greater than 10, which show that the matching effect is perfect.  

### 4.2. Innovation incentive effects of venture capital on NE enterprises  

Considering that the number of patent applications is a nonnegative discrete variable and does not meet the normal distribution required by linear regression, the Poisson model is used here to investigate the impact of venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprise. In Table 5, the model (1） examines the relationship between venture capital on the number of patent applications of NE enterprises, and the control variables were added to the model (2). Model (3) further controls the year and industry effects, and only selects the experimental group samples with the intervention of venture capital.The results show that the coefficients of venture capital amount in model (1)-(3) are 0.057, 0.010 and 0.034 respectively, and all pass the $1\%$ significance level test. Model (4) is the whole sample of the experimental group and the control group after applying PSM model, the coefficient of venture capital is 0.010 and passes the significance test at the $1\%$ level. For every $1\%$ increase in the amount of venture capital, the number of patent applications of NE enterprises increases by $1\%$ ,indicating that the venture capital has a positive and significant impact on the innovation of NE enterprise, and hypothesis H1 is established. This is consistent with the conclusions of Qi et al. (2017) [54]. New energy is a key strategic emerging industry in China. Venture capital focuses on long-term returns and can guide enterprise innovation by injecting capital into NE enterprise and providing management value-added services. Model (4) also shows that the coefficients of size and government subsidies are significantly positive (0.494 and 0.070) at the $1\%$ level, while the coefficients of roa and top10 are significantly negative $(-0.011$ and $-0.004)$ atthe $1\%$ level.This means that NE enterprises with larger size, higher government subsidies, declining profitability and lower equity concentration are more conducive to orderly innovation activities. Larger enterprises tend to possess abundant financial resources and innovation resources, and have stronger ability to bear innovation risks. Government subsidies can alleviate the innovation financing constraints of NE enterprises, and transmit the signal effect of strong innovation capabilities to the outside capital market. Both of which will support NE enterprises innovation.However, the stronger the profitability of NE enterprises is, the easier it is to rely on existing technologies to expand production to pursue economies of scale. If the NE enterprise's equity is over-concentrated, self-interested executives may easily be driven by interests to avoid investment in long-term and risky innovation activities. Both of them are not conducive to NE enterprises innovation. To further test the collinearity problem, the variance expandable factor (VIF) in the model (1) - model (4) is calculated. All VIF values are less than 0.5, indicating that the conclusion is not affected by multi-collinearity.

### 4.3. Innovation incentive effects of different types of venture capital sourcesonNEenterprises  

According to whether the venture capital institution has a government background, the whole NE enterprises have been divided into a government participation group and a nongovernment participation group. In Table 6, models (1) and (2) show that the coefficient of venture capital in government participation sample group is 0.031 and passes the significance test at the $1\%$ level, while the coefficient of the non-government participation sample group is 0.oo7 but insignificant. For every $1\%$ increase in the amount of government venture capital, the corresponding NE enterprise patent applications increase by $3.1\%$ indicatingthat compared with venture capital without government background, government participation venture capital has a more significant incentive effect on innovation of NE enterprises, and hypothesis H2 is established. This is in line with the conclusions of He (2019) [55]. Taking China's 569 GEM listed enterprises as samples, He (2019) also confirm that the innovation effect of government venture capital on enterprises is better than that of non-government venture capital [55]. A possible explanation is that government participation venture capital is more willing to attract private capital and provide abundant financial support for the innovation of NE enterprises. In addition, improving technological capability is the core strategic goal of the development of China's NE industry at the present stage, government participation venture capital is policy-guided and is easily affected by the innovation strategy of the NE industry, so it pays more efforts to promote the innovation capability oftheNEenterprises.  

In model (3) and model (4), the coefficient of venture capital in the joint venture capital group is 0.040 and passes the significance test at the $1\%$ level. When the amount of joint venture capital increasesby $1\%$ . the number of patent applications of NE enterprises increasesby $4\%$ . The coefficient of the independent venture capital groupis $-0.006$ but insignificant, indicating that compared with the independent venture capital, the joint venture capital has a more significant promoting effect on the innovation of NE enterprises. It is assumed that H3 is valid and is similar to the findings of Wen and Feng (2018) [56]. From the perspective of "value-added" and "exploitation", Wen and Feng (2018) find that joint venture capital can significantly stimulate enterprise innovation through providing value-added management services, while single venture capital tends to impede innovation for its expropriation behavior [56]. New energy is the key industry supported by Chinese government with high uncertainties of technology and market. Joint venture capital can bring diversified resources to NE enterprises and reduce innovation constraints caused by financing difficulties and talent shortages. Meanwhile, joint venture capital can provide a more complete social cooperation network to form a good strategic partnership between the invested NE enterprises, and therefore produce synergistic innovation effects.  

By manually inquiring the headquarters and office addresses of each venture capital institution and NE enterprises, the division of whether venture capital institutions invest locally is conducted.If venture capital institution and invested NE enterprise is located in the same province (autonomous region, municipality), it is defined as a local investment (model (5). Otherwise, it is a non-local investment (model (6)). In model (5) and model (6), the coefficients of venture capital in local investment group and non-local investment group are 0.049 and 0.012,both of which passes the significance test at the $1\%$ level. For every $1\%$ increase in the amount of localventure capital investment, the number of patent applications for NE enterprises will increase by $4.9\%$ and for every $1\%$ increase in the amount of non-local investment, the corresponding patents will increase by $1.2\%$ indicating that thelocal investment of venture capital institutions has a more significant effect on promoting the innovation of NE enterprises. It is assumed that H4 is established.

### 4.4.Innovation incentive effects of local investment by government participationventure capital and local investment byjoint venture capital onNEenterprises  

In practice, compared with non-government participation venture capital, government participation venture capital is mostly set up by local governments and prefers to implement local investment. Meanwhile, compared with independent venture capital, joint venture capital institutions implement local investment can leverage social networks and integratelocal resourcesfor enterprises innovation. Therefore, this paper further analyzes the impact of local investment by government participation venture capital and local investment by joint venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises. We firstly select all samples of local investment made by venture capital, and then group them separately by two different classification criteria: government and non-government participation, joint and independent. In Table 7, the coefficient of local investment by government participation venture capital in model (1) is 0.058 and the coefficient of local investment by nongovernment participation venture capital in model (2) is 0.040, both of which are all significant at the $1\%$ level. The results show that local investment of government participation venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting the innovation of NE enterprises,for every $1\%$ increase in the amount of local government venture capital investment, the number of patent applications for invested NE enterprises increases by $5.8\%$ .Thisis consistent with previous studies. Dong et al.(2019)[47]believes that government-sponsored venture capital is more inclined to make localized investment and has a better innovation effect on local enterprises than private venture capital. Tian et al. (2020) [58] also argues that with the increase of geographical distance, the impact of venture capital on enterprise innovation becomes smaller, and the innovation effect of government venture capital in a short distance is more significant. Since government participation venture capital is mostly set up by local governments with the policy goal of supporting local enterprises to innovate and start businesses, and NE enterprises are the key industries strongly supported by regional governments, local investment of government participation venture capital may provide NE enterprises with moreinnovationfunds and better guidancewith thecharacteristics of policy convenience and communication effectiveness than the local investment by non-government participation venturecapital.  

The coefficient of local investment by joint venture capital in model (3) is 0.051 and passes the significance test at the $1\%$ level, the coefficient of local investment by independent venture capital in model (4) is 0.029 and is significant at the $5\%$ level, indicating that local investment by joint venture capital plays a stronger role in promoting the innovation of NE enterprises. For every $1\%$ increase in the amount of local investment by joint venture capital, the number of patent applications for invested NE enterprises increasesby $5.1\%$ Joint investmenthas becomea new trend for venture capital institutions to effectively avoid investment risks and promote investment success [59]. Li et al.(2021) [60] believe that in order to eliminate the agency costs and investment barriers, choosing to cooperate with local venture capital institutions can improve the listing and performance of the invested enterprises. The innovation of NE industry relies on the collaborative innovation development of upstream and downstream supply chains. Local investment by joint venture capital can realize the connection of the network relationship of different venture capital institutions, acceleratetheintegration oflocalinnovationresources,andfurther reduce the scope of the innovation supply chain of NE enterprises. At the same time, local investment by joint venture capital have rich industry experience, and may promote the process of sharing heterogeneous innovation resources among native invested enterprises and stimulate the innovation of NE enterprises.

## 6. Conclusions and recommendations  

This paper selects listed NE enterprises from 2010 to 2017 as a research sample, examines the impact of venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises, and draws the following main conclusions. First, venture capital, as a new type of market-oriented financing method, can significantly promote the innovation of NE enterprises, which is manifested in the significant increase in the number of patent applications for NE enterprises. And, NE enterprises with larger size, higher government subsidies, declining profitability and lower equity concentration may also conducive to enterprises innovation. Second, compared with non-government participation, independent venture capital and non-localized investment of venture capital, government participation venture capital, joint venture capital and venture capital localized investment are more conducive to the innovation of NE enterprises. Third, government participation venture capital for localized investment and joint venture capital for localized investment have a more significant role in promoting the innovation of NE enterprises. Based on the above conclusions, this paper proposes the following policyrecommendations:  

First of all, under the background of gradual withdrawal of government subsidies, China needs to adopt credit incentives policies to vigorously promote the development of venture capital industry and form a market-based mechanism for venture capital to support the development of the NE industry. On this basis, give full play to the "incubation" role of venture capital to promote the innovation of NE industry. Secondly, new energy is a strategic emerging industry. It is necessary to make full use of the policy orientation and capital scale advantages of government participation venture capital to promote technological innovation of NE enterprises and thus improve the technological competitiveness of the NE industry. Third, as NE's technology and market are highly uncertain, the government should encourage venture capital institutions to choose joint investment to support the development of NE enterprises and avoid investment risks. Realize the innovation of NE enterprises by providing abundant talents, funds and more complete social network resources. Finally, the government should also encourage government participation and joint venture capital to accelerate the regional financial development of science and technology through local investment, and give full play to the innovation synergies produced by industrial agglomeration.  

This paper has the following deficiencies. (1) Since unlisted enterprises are not required to publish data,the samples used in this paper are all listed NE enterprises, and the data obtained from foreign venture capital investment in NE enterprises are very few. Therefore, we classify foreign venture capital and private venture capital as non-government venture capital, and cannot provide foreign venture capital and private venture capital separately. In future research, the impact of venture capital with different ownership characteristics on China's strategic NE industry should be enriched when sufficient data are available. (2) In terms of research methods, this paper applies Poisson regression to investigate the impact of venture capital on the innovation of NE enterprises.Since the use of quantile-to-quantile regression can investigate the effects of different combinations of independent variables on the dependent variable[61],to fully explore the complex effects of differentlevels ofventurecapital amounts on the different levels of innovation capability of NE enterprises, the quantile-to-quantile regression method should be adopted in the subsequent studies.

# And the Children Shall Lead: Gender Diversity and Performance in Venture Capital  

Paul A. Gompers Sophie Q. Wang  

![](images/49b50d592327355b6b3c6cef46e63c2c363b9a863b5b8ec837770dc1f9899b3d.jpg)  

# And the Children Shall Lead: Gender Diversity and Performance in Venture Capital  

Paul A. Gompers Harvard Business School  

Sophie Q. Wang Harvard University

# And the Children Shall Lead:  

## Gender Diversity and Performance in Venture Capital\*  

Paul A. Gompers Harvard Business Scbool and NBER paul@hbs.edu  

Sophie Q. Wang Harvard University qingzhenwang@fas.harvard.edu  

May 2017  

### Abstract  

With an overall lack of gender and ethnic diversity in the innovation sector documented in Gompers and Wang (2017), we ask the natural next question: Does increased diversity lead to better firm performances? In this paper, we attempt to answer this question using a unique dataset of the gender of venture capital partners’ children. First, we find strong evidence that parenting more daughters leads to an increased propensity to hire female partners by venture capital firms. Second, using an instrumental variable set-up, we also show that improved gender diversity, induced by parenting more daughters, improves deal and fund performances. These effects concentrate Overwhelmingly on the daughters of senior partners than junior partners. Taken together, our findings have profound implications on how the capital markets could function better with improved diversity.
